title: 109_s3985
content: The Act is titled the "Outer Continental Shelf Royalty Reform and Enhancement Act of 2006" and includes definitions. The Act defines "Gulf producing State" as Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas. It also defines "qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues" as certain payments to the United States, excluding certain types of revenues. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Revenues from leases under section 8(g) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are included. SEC. 3. The Secretary will limit royalty relief on oil and gas leases based on market prices for leases entered into after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Congress confirms the Secretary's authority to adjust royalty suspensions based on production prices for certain leases. SEC. 5. Revenue recovery from leases without price thresholds will be implemented. The Secretary will offer to amend payment responsibilities under leases for oil and gas production on the Outer Continental Shelf, providing relief from royalties without suspension based on price thresholds. Lessees will receive separate written offers within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary may enter into separate agreements with multiple persons who own a share of the lease. The offer will propose price thresholds consistent with previous Outer Continental Shelf leases. Additionally, the Secretary has the authority to increase royalty rates on leases for oil and gas production after the enactment of this Act. The Act allows for increased royalty rates on oil and gas production on the outer Continental Shelf to recover lost revenues from leases, aiming to recover $12 billion from 2007 to 2018. SEC. 6. DISPOSITION OF RECOVERED QUALIFIED OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF REVENUES. The Secretary of the Treasury shall deposit 50 percent of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues in a special account to be disbursed to Gulf producing States, 12.5 percent for financial assistance to States, and 37.5 percent of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues for other purposes. 37.5% of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues will be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction. The amounts will be made available in the fiscal year following the applicable fiscal year and will remain available until expended. These funds are in addition to any amounts appropriated under other acts. The curr_chunk states that the provision of law mentioned could be related to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act or any other law. SEC. 7. FEDERAL GUARANTEE OF STATE BOND. The Secretary will guarantee repayment of a bond issued by Louisiana for coastal wetland restoration projects and storm protection infrastructure using qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues. The bond amount must not exceed 80% of estimated revenues, funds must be used according to a state-submitted plan, and the bond must have legal guarantees for repayment.
